title: Cold Weather Cattle Management Webinar - March 12 2019

tasks.task: Presenters discussed various winter management issues for beef and dairy cattle, including body condition scoring, semen quality in bulls, calf cold stress, nutrition strategies, and pasture management.
subtasks: Lisa Peterson discussed body condition scoring for cows and bulls, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a body condition score of 5–7 at calving and semen quality in bulls.
Jerry Stucca addressed managing calves affected by cold stress, highlighting signs of cold stress, intervention methods, and the importance of colostrum.
Jana Block covered nutrition management during winter, focusing on forage quality, calculating energy requirements, and strategies to stretch limited hay supplies.
John Dubetter provided tips for stretching hay when supplies are low, including adjusting rations, feeding grain supplements, and managing cattle groups.
Carl Hoppe detailed available co-products sources in North Dakota (e.g., wheat middlings, distiller’s grains) and their benefits for supplementing low-quality forages.
Miranda Meehan discussed pasture and range turnout considerations, emphasizing the importance of plant development stages, timing of turnout, and avoiding stressed pastures.

tasks.task: Question and Answer session followed the presentations, addressing specific concerns from attendees.
subtasks: Panelists addressed questions related to colostrum feeding, grazing readiness, evening feeding effects on calving times, and diabetes warning signs in dairy cattle.
